column1: You have created a servlet that generates weather maps. The data for these maps is calculated by a remote host. The IP address of this host is usually stable, but occasionally does have to change as the corporate network grows and changes. This IP address used to be hard coded, but after the fifth change to the IP address in two years, you have decided that this value should be declared in the deployment descriptor so you do NOT have the recompile the web application every time the IP address changes. Which deployment descriptor snippet accomplishes this goal?

column1: Your company has a corporate policy that prohibits storing a customer's credit card number in any corporate database. However, users have complained that they do NOT want to re- enter their credit card number for each transaction. Your management has decided to use client-side cookies to record the user's credit card number for 120 days. Furthermore, they also want to protect this information during transit from the web browser to the web container; so the cookie must only be transmitted over HTTPS. Which code snippet creates the "creditCard" cookie and adds it to the out going response to be stored on the user's web browser?

Furthermore, they also want to protect this information during transit from the web browser to the web container; so the cookie must only be transmitted over HTTPS. Which code snippet creates the "creditCard" cookie and adds it to the out going response to be stored on the user's web browser?

You are building a web application that will be used throughout the European Union; therefore, it has significant internationalization requirements. You have been tasked to create a custom tag that generates a message using the java.text.MessageFormat class. The tag will take the resourceKey attribute and a variable number of argument attributes with the format, arg<N>. Here is an example use of this tag and its output: <t:message resourceKey='diskFileMsg' arg0='MyDisk' arg1='1247' /> generates: The disk "MyDisk" contains 1247 file( s). Which Simple tag class definition accomplishes this goal of handling a variable number of tag attributes?

What is true about Java EE authentication mechanisms?
column2: If your deployment descriptor correctly declares an authentication type of CLIENT_CERT, your users must have a certificate from an official source before they can use your application.

column1: What is true about Java EE authentication mechanisms?
column2: If your deployment descriptor correctly declares an authentication type of BASIC, the container automatically requests a user name and password whenever a user starts a new session.

column1: What is true about Java EE authentication mechanisms?
column2: If you want your web application to support the widest possible array of browsers, and you want to perform authentication, the best choice of Java EE authentication mechanisms is DIGEST.

column1: What is true about Java EE authentication mechanisms?
column2: To use Java EE FORM authentication, you must declare two HTML files in your deployment descriptor, and you must use a predefined action in the HTML file that handles your user's login.

 <% if (  request.getSession( false) == null ) count++; %>

You have created a servlet that generates weather maps. The data for these maps is calculated by a remote host. The IP address of this host is usually stable, but occasionally does have to change as the corporate network grows and changes. This IP address used to be hard coded, but after the fifth change to the IP address in two years, you have decided that this value should be declared in the deployment descriptor so you do NOT have the recompile the web application every time the IP address changes. <br />
 <br />
 Which deployment descriptor snippet accomplishes this goal?

A developer for the company web site has been told that users may turn off cookie support in their browsers. What must the developer do to ensure that these customers can still use the web application?
column2: The developer must ensure that every URL is properly encoded using the appropriate URL rewriting APIs.

column1: A developer for the company web site has been told that users may turn off cookie support in their browsers. What must the developer do to ensure that these customers can still use the web application?
column2: The developer must provide an alternate mechanism for managing sessions and abandon the HttpSession mechanism entirely.

column1: A developer for the company web site has been told that users may turn off cookie support in their browsers. What must the developer do to ensure that these customers can still use the web application?
column2: The developer can ignore this issue. Web containers are required to support automatic URL rewriting when cookies are not supported.

column1: A developer for the company web site has been told that users may turn off cookie support in their browsers. What must the developer do to ensure that these customers can still use the web application?
column2: The developer must add the string id=<sessionid> to the end of every URL to ensure that the conversation with the browser can continue.

A session-scoped attribute, product, is stored by a servlet. That servlet then forwards to a JSP page. This attribute holds an instance of the com.example.Product class with a name property of "The Matrix" and price property of 39.95. Given the JSP page code snippet:<br />
 1. <jsp:useBean id='product' class='com.example.Product'><br />
 2. <jsp:setProperty name='product' property='price' value='49.95'/><br />
 3. </jsp:useBean><br />
 4. <%= product.getName(  ) %> costs <%= product.getPrice(  ) %> <br />
 <br />
 What is the response output of this JSP page code snippet?

column1:
A developer is working on a project that includes both EJB 2.1 and EJB 3.0 session beans. A lot of business logic has been implemented and tested in these EJB 2.1 session beans.<br />
 <br />
 Some EJB 3.0 session beans need to access this business logic.<br />
 <br />
 Which design approach can achieve this requirement?
column2: Add adapted home interfaces to EJB 3.0 session beans to make EJB 3.0 and EJB 2.1 session beans interoperable.

column1:
A developer is working on a project that includes both EJB 2.1 and EJB 3.0 session beans. A lot of business logic has been implemented and tested in these EJB 2.1 session beans.<br />
 <br />
 Some EJB 3.0 session beans need to access this business logic.<br />
 <br />
 Which design approach can achieve this requirement?
column2: Add EJB 3.0 business interfaces to existing EJB 2.1 session beans and inject references to these business interfaces into EJB 3.0 session beans.

column1:
A developer is working on a project that includes both EJB 2.1 and EJB 3.0 session beans. A lot of business logic has been implemented and tested in these EJB 2.1 session beans.<br />
 <br />
 Some EJB 3.0 session beans need to access this business logic.<br />
 <br />
 Which design approach can achieve this requirement?
column2:
No need to modify existing EJB 2.1 session beans. Use the @EJB annotation to inject a reference to the EJB
 2.1 home interface into the EJB 3.0 bean class.

 <br />
 Which design approach can achieve this requirement?
column2:

 2.1 component interface into the EJB 3.0 bean class.

Consider the contents of three JSP files:<br />
 File 1: one.jsp<br> <br />
     <html><body><pre><br> <br />
        <jsp:include page="two.jsp" ><br> <br />
           <jsp:param name="color" value="red" /><br> <br />
        </jsp:include><br> <br />
     </pre></body></html><br> <br />
 File 2: two.jsp<br> <br />
     <jsp:include page="three.jsp" ><br> <br />
        <jsp:param name="color" value="green" /><br> <br />
     </jsp:include><br> <br />
 File 3: three.jsp<br> <br />
    <%= request.getParameter( "color")  %><br> <br />
 What will be the output of accessing the one.jsp file via the following URL? <br />
  <br />
 http://localhost:8080/chapter12/one.jsp?color=blue

A developer is working on a project that includes both EJB 2.1 and EJB 3.0 session beans. A lot of business logic has been implemented and tested in these EJB 2.1 session beans.<br />
 <br />
 Some EJB 3.0 session beans need to access this business logic.<br />
 <br />
 Which design approach can achieve this requirement?
column2: Add adapted home interfaces to EJB 3.0 session beans to make EJB 3.0 and EJB 2.1 session beans interoperable.

column1:
A developer is working on a project that includes both EJB 2.1 and EJB 3.0 session beans. A lot of business logic has been implemented and tested in these EJB 2.1 session beans.<br />
 <br />
 Some EJB 3.0 session beans need to access this business logic.<br />
 <br />
 Which design approach can achieve this requirement?
column2: Add EJB 3.0 business interfaces to existing EJB 2.1 session beans and inject references to these business interfaces into EJB 3.0 session beans.

column1:
A developer is working on a project that includes both EJB 2.1 and EJB 3.0 session beans. A lot of business logic has been implemented and tested in these EJB 2.1 session beans.<br />
 <br />
 Some EJB 3.0 session beans need to access this business logic.<br />
 <br />
 Which design approach can achieve this requirement?
column2:
No need to modify existing EJB 2.1 session beans. Use the @EJB annotation to inject a reference to the EJB
 2.1 home interface into the EJB 3.0 bean class.

Consider the contents of two JSP files:<br>
 File 1: this.jsp<br> <br>
   <html><body><pre><br> <br>
      <jsp:include page="that.jsp" ><br> <br>
         <jsp:param name="color" value="red" /><br> <br>
         <jsp:param name="color" value="green" /><br> <br>
      </jsp:include><br> <br>
   </pre></body></html><br> <br>
 File 2: that.jsp<br> <br>
   <%<br> <br>
      String colors[] = request.getParameterValues( "color");<br> <br>
      for ( int i=0; i<colors.length; i++)<br> <br>
      {<br> <br>
    out.print( colors[i] + " ");<br> <br>
      }<br> <br>
   %><br><br> <br>
 What will be the output of accessing the this.jsp file via the following URL? <br>
 ( Select one)<br>
   http://localhost:8080/chapter12/this.jsp?color=blue

Your company has a corporate policy that prohibits storing a customer's credit card number in any corporate database. However, users have complained that they do NOT want to re- enter their credit card number for each transaction. Your management has decided to use client-side cookies to record the user's credit card number for 120 days. Furthermore, they also want to protect this information during transit from the web browser to the web container; so the cookie must only be transmitted over HTTPS. Which code snippet creates the "creditCard" cookie and adds it to the out going response to be stored on the user's web browser?

You are building a web application that will be used throughout the European Union; therefore, it has significant internationalization requirements. You have been tasked to create a custom tag that generates a message using the java.text.MessageFormat class. The tag will take the resourceKey attribute and a variable number of argument attributes with the format, arg<N>. Here is an example use of this tag and its output: <t:message resourceKey='diskFileMsg' arg0='MyDisk' arg1='1247' /> generates: The disk "MyDisk" contains 1247 file( s). Which Simple tag class definition accomplishes this goal of handling a variable number of tag attributes?

Consider the contents of two JSP files:<br />
 File 1: this.jsp<br> <br />
   <html><body><pre><br> <br />
      <jsp:include page="that.jsp" ><br> <br />
         <jsp:param name="color" value="red" /><br> <br />
         <jsp:param name="color" value="green" /><br> <br />
      </jsp:include><br> <br />
   </pre></body></html><br> <br />
 File 2: that.jsp<br> <br />
   <%<br> <br />
      String colors[] = request.getParameterValues( "color");<br> <br />
      for ( int i=0; i<colors.length; i++)<br> <br />
      {<br> <br />
    out.print( colors[i] + " ");<br> <br />
      }<br> <br />
   %><br><br> <br />
 What will be the output of accessing the this.jsp file via the following URL? <br />
 ( Select one)<br />
   http://localhost:8080/chapter12/this.jsp?color=blue

Consider the contents of three JSP files:<br />
 File 1: one.jsp<br> <br />
     <html><body><pre><br> <br />
        <jsp:include page="two.jsp" ><br> <br />
           <jsp:param name="color" value="red" /><br> <br />
        </jsp:include><br> <br />
     </pre></body></html><br> <br />
 File 2: two.jsp<br> <br />
     <jsp:include page="three.jsp" ><br> <br />
        <jsp:param name="color" value="green" /><br> <br />
     </jsp:include><br> <br />
 File 3: three.jsp<br> <br />
    <%= request.getParameter( "color")  %><br> <br />
 What will be the output of accessing the one.jsp file via the following URL? <br />
 ( Select one)<br />
     http://localhost:8080/chapter12/one.jsp?color=blue

Identify the correct order of phases in the Public/Private Key encryption?<br>
 <br>
 1. Server provides its public key <br>

 4. Client provides its public key, encrypted with the server's public key

column1: Why should we use RequestDispatcher to forward a request to another resource, instead of using a sendRedirect?
column2: The RequestDispatcher does not require a round trip to the client, and thus is more efficient and allows the server to maintain the request state.

column1: What is the difference between doing an include and a forward with a RequestDispatcher?
column2: The two methods provide the same functionality, but with different levels of persistence.

column1: What is the difference between doing an include and a forward with a RequestDispatcher?
column2: The forward method is deprecated as of JSP 1.1 and the include method should be used in order to substitute portions of a dynamic display at runtime.

column1: What is the difference between doing an include and a forward with a RequestDispatcher?
column2: The include method transfers control to a dynamic resource, while the forward method allows for dynamic substitution of another JPS pages.

column1: What is the difference between doing an include and a forward with a RequestDispatcher?
column2: The forward method transfers control to the designated resource, while the include method invokes the designated resource, substitutes its output dynamically in the display, and returns control to the calling page.

column1: <p>Which of the following statements describing the stateless nature of HTTP protocol and the need of tracking client identity and state are true?<br>(A) When the configuration setting, transactions, and information are not tracked<br>by the protocol, then it is called stateless protocol.<br>(B) The HTTP protocol is based on a client-server model.<br>(C) The HTTP protocol sends an acknowledgement that the information sent by the<br>server has reached the client.<br>(D) Session tracking allows the server to keep a track of successive requests made<br>by the same client.<br>(E) In HTTP protocol, the loss of data can be easily detected.<br></p>

<p>HTTP is a ______________ layer protocol.<br>(A) Filter was introduced as a Web component in Java servlet Specification version 2.3.<br>(B) A filter optimizes the time it takes to send back a response from your Web server.<br>(C) A logging and auditing filter allows users to log in to a Web application.<br>(D) Filter optimizes the available bandwidth on the network thereby reducing the network traffic and in turn increasing the efficiency of all Web-based services.<br>(E) An authentication filter tracks the activities of users of a Web application.<br></p>

<p>Match the elements to their appropriate features.<br>Feature: <br>(A)This element inside the deployment descriptor holds the name of the filter to which a URL pattern or servlet is mapped.<br>(B)This specifies the location of a small or a large image used to represent the filter in a GUI tool within a Web application.<br>(C) It holds the name and value pair of an initialization parameter of the filter. <br>(D)This element specifies the name of a servlet whose request and response will be modified by the filter.  <br>(E) This is the short name of the filter, i.e. intended to be displayed by GUI tools. <br>Element:<br>(1) <icon><br>(2) <init-param><br>(3) <filter-name><br>(4) <display-name><br>(5) <servlet-name><br></p>

<p>Following is the code for doGet() and doPost() method of TestServlet. </p><p>public class TestServlet extends HttpServlet {</p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doGet(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        doPost(request, response);<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doPost(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        response.getWriter().println("This is doPost!");<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>}<br></p><p>Which of the statement is correct? </p>
column2: This will only work for HTTP GET requests

column1: <p>Following is the code for doGet() and doPost() method of TestServlet. </p><p>public class TestServlet extends HttpServlet {</p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doGet(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        doPost(request, response);<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doPost(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        response.getWriter().println("This is doPost!");<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>}<br></p><p>Which of the statement is correct? </p>
column2: This will only work for HTTP POST requests

column1: <p>Following is the code for doGet() and doPost() method of TestServlet. </p><p>public class TestServlet extends HttpServlet {</p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doGet(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        doPost(request, response);<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doPost(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        response.getWriter().println("This is doPost!");<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>}<br></p><p>Which of the statement is correct? </p>
column2: This will work for HTTP GET as well as POST requests.

column1: <p>Following is the code for doGet() and doPost() method of TestServlet. </p><p>public class TestServlet extends HttpServlet {</p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doGet(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        doPost(request, response);<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>    @Override<br></p><p>    protected void doPost(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</p><p>        response.getWriter().println("This is doPost!");<br></p><p>    }<br></p><p>}<br></p><p>Which of the statement is correct? </p>
column2: It'll throw an exception at runtime, as you can not call doPost() from doGet().

<p>Given the following deployment descriptor:</p><web-app><br /><servlet><br /><servlet-name>InitParams</servlet-name><br /><servlet-class>com.osborne.c02.InitParamsServlet</servlet-class><br /><init-param><br /><param-name>initParm</param-name><br /><param-value>Final Test</param-value><br /></init-param><br /></servlet><br /></web-app><br />
<p>What is the outcome of running the following servlet? </p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace"><strong>public class InitParamsServlet extends HttpServlet</strong> { </font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace"><font color="#0033cc">protected void doGet</font>(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">ServletContext sc = this.getServletContext();</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">PrintWriter out = response.getWriter();</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">out.write("Initialization Parameter is: " + sc.getInitParameter("initParm"));</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">}</font></p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">} </font>

<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace"><font color="#0033cc">protected void doGet</font>(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">ServletContext sc = this.getServletContext();</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">PrintWriter out = response.getWriter();</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">out.write("Initialization Parameter is: " + sc.getInitParameter("initParm"));</font></p>
<p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">}</font></p><font face="courier new,courier,monospace">} </font>
column2: "Initialization Parameter is: Final Test" returned to the requester

<p align="justify">A web application uses the HttpSession mechanism to determine if a user in “logged in”. When a user supplies a valid username and password, an HttpSession is created for that user. </p>
<p align="justify">The user has access to the application for only 15 minutes after logging in. The code must determine how long the user has been logged in, and if this time is greater than 15 minutes, must destroy the HttpSession </p>
<p align="justify">Which method in HttpSession is used to accomplish this? </p>

<p align="justify">A web application uses the HttpSession mechanism to determine if a user in “logged in”. When a user supplies a valid username and password, an HttpSession is created for that user. </p>
<p align="justify">The user has access to the application for only 15 minutes after logging in. The code must determine how long the user has been logged in, and if this time is greater than 15 minutes, must destroy the HttpSession </p>
<p align="justify">Which method in HttpSession is used to accomplish this? </p>

<p align="justify">A web application uses the HttpSession mechanism to determine if a user in “logged in”. When a user supplies a valid username and password, an HttpSession is created for that user. </p>

<p>The Servlet.java contains the following code.</p><p>protected void processRequest(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response)<br>            throws ServletException, IOException {<br>        response.setContentType("text/html;charset=UTF-8");<br>            /* TODO output your page here. You may use following sample code. */<br>            out.println("<!DOCTYPE html>");<br>            out.println("<html>");<br>            out.println("<head>");<br>            out.println("<title>Servlet HelloServlet</title>");            <br>            out.println("</head>");<br>            out.println("<body>");<br>            String f1 = (String)request.getAttribute("f1");<br>            out.println(f1 + "<br/>");<br>            out.println("</body>");<br>            out.println("</html>");<br>            out.close();<br>    }</p><p>The Filter.java contains the following code.<br>public void doFilter(ServletRequest request, ServletResponse response,<br>            FilterChain chain)<br>            throws IOException, ServletException {<br>            request.setAttribute("f1", "Request Filter 1");<br>            chain.doFilter(request, response);<br>            PrintWriter out = response.getWriter();<br>            out.println(" Response Filter 1 ");<br>            out.close();<br>    }</p><p>What is the client output?<br></p>
